citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
***At the time of inspection there was no written program of veterinary care available for review. Lack of written
veterinarian instructions can lead to missed medical prevention recommendations for health promotion to all animals. The
applicant must have a written program of veterinary care as required.

***In the Rabbit area, there was an enclosure containing two Rabbits. The front center brace board of the enclosure had
been chewed completely through at the bottom leaving two screws exposed upward approximately 1". One of the Rabbits
was observed chewing on one of the screws.
Sharp points and edges protruding into an enclosure create a potential injury for the animals within the enclosure. The
applicant must remove the protruding screw ends and assure that enclosures are structurally sound and maintained in
good repair to protect the rabbits from injury as required.

***There was an enclosure that contained two Wallabies, two Cavies and four Chickens. There was a hole cut into the
metal sheet so these animals could get into an enclosure in the barn. The bottom piece of metal had become detached
and was bent outward into the outdoor portion of the enclosure, creating sharp points and edges.
Sharp points and edges protruding into an enclosure create a potential injury for the animals within the enclosure. The
applicant must repair the detached metal and entrance area and assure enclosures are structurally sound and maintained
in good repair to protect the animals from injury.

***In the garage, there was an enclosure containing one Scarlet McCaw that was blind. The perch was held on one end
by wire. The end of this wire was protruding into the enclosure and the McCaw was observed attempting to chew on the
wire.
Sharp points and edges protruding into an enclosure create a potential injury for the animals within the enclosure. The
applicant must remove the wire ends from the enclosure and assure that there are no sharp points or edges in the primary
enclosures as required.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class C license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by May 21, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
***At the time of inspection there was no written program of veterinary care available for review. Lack of written 
veterinarian instructions can lead to missed medical prevention recommendations for health promotion to all animals. The 
applicant must have a written program of veterinary care as required. 
3.53(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
***In the Rabbit area, there was an enclosure containing two Rabbits. The front center brace board of the enclosure had 
been chewed completely through at the bottom leaving two screws exposed upward approximately 1". One of the Rabbits 
was observed chewing on one of the screws.  
Sharp points and edges protruding into an enclosure create a potential injury for the animals within the enclosure. The 
applicant must remove the protruding screw ends and assure that enclosures are structurally sound and maintained in 
good repair to protect the rabbits from injury as required. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
***There was an enclosure that contained two Wallabies, two Cavies and four Chickens. There was a hole cut into the 
metal sheet so these animals could get into an enclosure in the barn. The bottom piece of metal had become detached 
and was bent outward into the outdoor portion of the enclosure, creating sharp points and edges.  
Sharp points and edges protruding into an enclosure create a potential injury for the animals within the enclosure. The 
applicant must repair the detached metal and entrance area and assure enclosures are structurally sound and maintained 
in good repair to protect the animals from injury. 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
***In the garage, there was an enclosure containing one Scarlet McCaw that was blind. The perch was held on one end 
by wire. The end of this wire was protruding into the enclosure and the McCaw was observed attempting to chew on the 
wire.  
Sharp points and edges protruding into an enclosure create a potential injury for the animals within the enclosure. The

applicant must remove the wire ends from the enclosure and assure that there are no sharp points or edges in the primary 
enclosures as required. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class C license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by May 21, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
